segments.text: Then he went on to note that as his notoriety as a splendid hurdler broadened, a reporter for the Beaumont Enterprise inquired where he planned to go to college
And he responded that he assumed he'd go to the University of Texas since they had a good team.
The next day, the day after the appearance of the article, he recalled that, quote, a little man knocked on his front door, quote, and
soon told him that he was, quote, too fine a person to go to the University of Texas.
He should be an Aggie.
That same gentleman promised that he would get 100 Aggies to write letters of encouragement to this trackster.
who then smiled and recall that the letters did come and that there was, quote, not a penny of bribe in any of them, comma, quote, but that Mr Babcock's intervention in his plan
had changed his had altered his life.
A redirection for which he would always be grateful.
Another example of the.
Changes at A&M and the role.
And the key role of Earl Rudder.
was linked to integration.
Mr. Rutter was by that time a major general in the U.S. Army Reserve and thus was well acquainted with the routine of the Department of Defense.
As the time came for
enrollment of the first black students.
I understand that Major General Rutter called the appropriate office in the Pentagon and requested that when they sent, when they identified the enlisted personnel
to be sent at Army expense to A&M to complete their undergraduate degrees, that they include some black soldiers.
He continued to urge that those men be carefully reviewed so that there would be no difficulty about their academic record.
or other uh background matters then president rudder directed lloyd heaton the veteran registrar and director of admissions to review the transcript of these men
and to ensure that they were enrolled in the proper summer courses.
Since registration at that time was conducted either in Sabisa Hall or G. Riley White Coliseum, it was an old-fashioned affair where everyone stood in line and waited their turn.
Mr. Rutter
saw such a routine as having the potential for an incident, or perhaps even some protesters.
So he told Mr. Heaton, whom I had heard earlier to say,

that it would be, quote, over his dead body that a black student ever enrolled at A&M, comma, quote, that Heaton was to ensure that the students were in the appropriate sections and that he was to personally call each of the instructors
of those courses to inform them that these enlisted men had been fully admitted and were appropriately enrolled.
Since registration was on a Monday afternoon, those calls were on Monday morning, those calls were made Monday afternoon and the first

knowledge that the public had of integration at the land-grant school was when a news report was announced that evening on radio and television that for the first time in its history, Texas A&M had enrolled
black students had attended classes at Texas A&M that morning.
There was not a single problem, never an incident, and racial integration probably moved more quietly and smoothly at A&M
than at any other major institution in the nation.
Meanwhile, I overlooked back as I was going through Austin, overlooked the end of the item on the name change, and this should be taken back.
Vice President Hall recalled not long ago
that Mr. Rutter simply could not accept the drop, the change to Texas State University because it would mean the loss of the traditional identifier A&M.

Dr. Hall said it was he who created the idea and offered the proposal that the name simply become simply Texas A&M University with no periods after the initial A or M and that the there be an ampersand
Instead of the.
Word a indeed.
For Mr Rutter, that was a.
Very positive alternative.
And thus.
The effort proceeded smoothly.
Gradually women began to be admitted.
with less difficulty at the undergraduate level and the enrollment moved forward.
As we entered the year of 1970, which would mark
Mr Rudder's 60th birthday.
Most of us were unaware that he was having health worries.
During that spring complications from both heart and liver attacked him at almost simultaneously.
and he died one month before his 60th birthday, thus making him ineligible for many veterans' benefits.
Not even his classmate, Congressman Olin E. Tiger T., could obtain an exception to the 60-year policy.
The board of directors appointed Clyde Freeman, appointed retired Lieutenant General Alvin Ludeke, Mike Teague and Rudder, a member of the class of 31, as the interim president.
General Ludeke had earned a remarkable, had created a remarkable record of leadership success in directing the
federal laboratory in California where the military rocket research efforts had been notable for their lack of success until he became the director of the Jet Propulsion Lab, JPL.
Quiet in his demeanor.
And always well organized.
A&M proceeded forward.
Meanwhile.
Unknown to most of us.
The board.
had acted upon the advice of Earl Rudder in seeking a replacement.
Back in the summer of 1968, Fort Albritton, class of 41 or 42, I think, can look that up,
The founding president and CEO of All Britain Engineering, Alenco, a booming little industry in Bryan, had proudly bought his company's first jet plane.
For a number of months, he had been trying to persuade President Rudder
to select a national public relations firm to begin to market A&M on a well-organized basis to a larger
That effort, that effort bore fruit when All Britain and his classmate, dear friend, John Lindsay picked Mr.
Rudder up for a flight to Chicago to visit with the PR firm.

As Mr. Albritton recalls, they were somewhere over the Midwest, quote, somewhere over the Midwest, quote, when he turned to the A&M president and proudly noted the growth and progress fully underway on the campus.
Then he asked Mr. Rutter what would be the circumstances regarding continued leadership if, quote, God help us, something were to happen to you.
Do you have someone in place that could step in?
Hesitantly, the A&M president noted that he had learned in battle in the battlefields in Western Europe that you, quote, always need an adjutant because any commanding officer may go down in battle.
But at the present time, he had no one of that sort and that he would have to work on it.
the two traveling companions dropped the subject.
But then that evening over supper, then during dinner that evening, all Britain returned to the topic and inquired again.
He remembered
that Mr.
Rudder smiled and said, I've been thinking about it since this afternoon, and if anything ever happened to me, you need to go to Tennessee and talk to Jack Kenny Williams, period, quote.
The NM president noted that Williams had been the first commissioner of higher education for Texas,
Thus had organized the Coordinating Board.
And had worked with real skill and success.
With the state legislature.
Public schools.
And all of the key leaders.
In the state.
Further, he noted.
That Williams.
Following a splendid.
record of valor and achievement as a Marine in the Pacific in World War II.
Had joined the faculty at Clemson University as a junior historian and worked his way up to the position as chief academic officer

during the years that that separate land grant school in a southern state located off the main highway about a hundred miles from the state capitol where the state university was located and where whose
supporters told Clemson jokes.
A situation very much like Texas A&M and its realities in the Lone Star State.
More, most importantly, he added that Clemson
had changed from being an all-male, racially segregated institution with a comparatively narrow curriculum and a mandatory military organization for all freshmen and sophomores
and had changed all of those policies during the Williams years.
Thus, he could understand A&M well.
At the time of Mr. Rutter's passing, All Britain was a new member of the board of directors.
And in executive session, he shared, quote, Earl's recommendations with his colleagues.
Quickly, the group decided to fly to Tennessee to interview Dr. Williams, who was the chief academic officer for the University of Tennessee system.
All of the director, A&M directors except one, went on the trip.
And the lone absentee who had a business commitment that he simply could not reschedule, truly could not reschedule,
were so impressed with Jack Williams that they agreed unanimously on site that he was the new president.
Sadly, All Britain noted that the absentee
future Senator Peyton McKnight, P-E-Y-T-O-N, of Tyler, was so enraged that his director colleagues had reached a decision without him that he voted against Dr. Williams' appointment and later
shook his finger in the new president's face as he informed him, I voted against you and I will be against you as long as you were here.
Paragraph.
I learned of Dr. Williams' selection through a phone call from George Kunze, the dean of the graduate school.
a soil mineralogist who had grown up near Warda in a Windish family, W-E-N-D-I-S-H.
I had the pleasure and honor of working with Dr. Kunze in the graduate college for almost three years.
That appointment began unexpectedly after I invited Dr. Wayne Hall to speak to the History Club about going to graduate school and what kind of record it took
for a undergraduate to be admitted to top flight graduate programs.
Stevens and I were the volunteer advisors to the club and tried to place before those hopeful students individuals who might help
encourage future attainment.
Following the presentation, Dr. Hall and his associate graduate dean, Bill Barzyk, asked me to walk back to their office in the Koch building with them.
Bill and I had
been the co-drafters of the entire aspirations report with his having responsibility for the portion on research and the experiment stations and extension service while I did the RISL portion.
When we reached
the Koch building I was pleasantly surprised when they asked me if I would be willing to join them as the assistant dean of the graduate school on a half-time basis.
I asked them if I might still teach and they said of course I might so I devoted
I taught two sections, continued to teach two sections of history while serving as assistant graduate dean.
In addition, I had accepted the assignment from my dissertation advisor, Frank Vandiver,
as the founding editor of the papers in Jefferson Davis.
Paragraph.
Following the completion of my dissertation, I dreamed of doing a book-length project on the creation of the Confederate States of America, particularly the government of the
independent South during the period that it located during the period from the secession of South Carolina in December 1860 until the movement of the CSA capital to Richmond in June of 1861.
Beginning in the summer of 61,
The research on that project took me and the family on the road each summer.
Within two summers, Vandiver had come up with the Civil War Centennial Commission.
The National Civil War Centennial Commission had
reached a decision to support the publication of the, and underline this as title, the papers of Ulysses S. Grant and the papers of Jefferson Davis.
Vandiver saw this as a two-volume project, the Davis project as a two-volume effort, and asked me as I went around
to libraries and other depositories looking for materials related to the founding of the Independent South about Davis materials.
At the end of the summer, I reported back to him that all of the librarians had indicated they would not share

copies of their materials if it was only going to be a selective project but would cooperate fully if the plan was modified to include all Davis correspondence to and from Davis and his speeches and other appropriate materials.
Meanwhile, he had reached the same conclusion
and he became the director of the Jefferson Davis effort and selected me as the editor.
I had been going to Houston two afternoons a week, Tuesday and Thursday afternoon,
just leaving the campus at about 11 o'clock, so I was at Rice from 1 until 6 o'clock or so.
Thus, I was teaching two sections, spending two half days a week at Rice, and now would undertake the halftime task
assistant dean of the graduate under programs which under the new nomenclature at A&M was identified as the Graduate College.
Paragraph working with Dr. Hall and Bill Barzac was very meaningful
because I was able to view.
